attributes.title: Ginseng for the treatment and prevention of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
attributes.description: Ginseng is a traditional herbal medicine often used as a complementary therapy to boost the immune system against infections. The main ginseng species used in clinical practice are Korean ginseng (Panax ginseng), American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius), and Chinese ginseng (Panax notoginseng). The aim of the review is to assess whether ginseng can be a useful integrative supplementation for the treatment or prevention of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections (SAURIs).

q1.value: Michele Antonelli, Davide Donelli, Fabio Firenzuoli

q2.value: To assess whether ginseng can be a useful supplementation for the prevention and treatment of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q9.value: Overall, existing data substantially suggest that ginseng might have some effects for seasonal acute upper respiratory infections, but firm conclusions on the topic cannot be driven.

question.value:
Searches.
Main sources: MEDLINE, EMBASE, Web of Science, Scopus, Cochrane Library, and Google Scholar. 
Additional sources: The Clinical Trials Register of the U.S. National Library of Medicine (ClinicalTrials.gov), the European Union Clinical Trials Register, and the Chinese Clinical Trial Registry.
All sources will be searched up to 01 November 2019.
No restrictions for publication period will be applied.
Articles written in one of the following languages will be considered: English, French, Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese.
Unpublished studies will not be sought.

Example of a search strategy.
Search strategy for MEDLINE, searched through PubMed:
(ginseng[Title/Abstract] OR panax[Title/Abstract] OR notoginseng[Title/Abstract] OR quinquefolius[Title/Abstract] OR ginsenoside[Title/Abstract] OR gintonin[Title/Abstract]) AND (influenza[Title/Abstract] OR "influenza-like"[Title/Abstract] OR flu[Title/Abstract] OR "flu-like"[Title/Abstract] OR rhinitis[Title/Abstract] OR cold[Title/Abstract] OR respiratory[Title/Abstract])

Condition being studied.
Seasonal acute upper respiratory infections represent infectious conditions of viral etiology like influenza or common cold, which are likely to occur during winter; over 200 different viruses can cause acute upper respiratory infections, and such viruses belong to 6 families: orthomyxoviruses (influenza), paramyxoviruses (respiratory syncytial virus), parainfluenza viruses, coronaviruses, picornaviruses (common cold), herpes viruses and adenoviruses (Eccles, R. (2002). An explanation for the seasonality of acute upper respiratory tract viral infections. Acta oto-laryngologica, 122(2), 183-191.). Among them, the most important ones are flu viruses. Influenza or flu is defined by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) as a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses, which can be responsible for mild to severe sickness. Influenza viruses cause seasonal flu epidemics each year. Source: https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/index.html 

PICOS criteria
Population.
Inclusion: Patients (any age) with seasonal acute upper respiratory infections (e.g.: influenza or cold), reporting at least a respiratory symptom like running nose, sneezing, cough, sore throat, nasal or sinus congestion, in combination with at least a systemic symptom like fever, chills, myalgia, fatigue, headache. All participants will be included regardless of their comorbidities. 
Exclusion: Patients affected by non-respiratory or chronic infections.
Intervention.
Inclusion: The oral administration of any extract obtained from ginseng (Panax ginseng, Panax notoginseng, or Panax quinquefolius) at any dosage over a well-defined period (regardless of its duration). 
Exclusion: The administration of a multi-component remedy including ginseng, unless ginseng is the main component of the formulation accounting for the majority (>90%) of its composition.
Control.
Any type of comparison (placebo, no treatment, treatment-as-usual), including no comparison.
Types of study to be included.
Inclusion: any study involving humans, both clinical trials and observational studies.
Exclusion: preclinical studies with laboratory animals or cellular models.

Main outcomes.
Therapeutic outcome: Duration, severity, and symptoms of the acute upper respiratory infection.
Preventive outcome: incidence of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections during the study period.

Additional outcomes.
Adverse events reported in each included study.

Study selection and data extraction.
Study selection: Two reviewers (M.A.; D.D.) will independently screen and select studies for inclusion in the systematic review. Disagreements between individual judgements will be resolved with the discussion of each decision with a third author (F.F.) until consensus is reached. The entire procedure will be performed with the help of a dedicated software (EndNote Program).
Data extraction: The following data will be extracted: participant demographics and baseline characteristics, details regarding intervention (e.g.: ginseng type, dose, duration of administration) and comparison type, outcome measures (duration, severity, and symptoms of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections; incidence of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections during the study period; microbial etiology of respiratory infections; reported adverse events) and information about study design. Influenza vaccination status of participants was also recorded. 
One reviewer (M.A.) will manually extract data from included studies, while another one (D.D.) will perform an additional check to ensure the correctness of extracted data by the first reviewer. Disagreements between individual judgements will be resolved with the discussion of each decision with a third author until consensus is reached. In case of missing, unreported or additional data, study investigators will be contacted by email. Data will be recorded in an excel spreadsheet and will be manually extracted from included articles without the help of any software.

q11.value: Not applicable. The review is to be performed regardless of the number of included primary studies.

question.value:
Duration, severity, and symptoms of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections. 
Incidence of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections during the study period.
Microbial etiology of respiratory infections. 
Reported adverse events.

Strategy for data synthesis.
Data synthesis will be conducted per trial arm, thus using aggregated data rather than individual participant data. If studies are sufficiently homogeneous in terms of design and characteristics, a quantitative synthesis will be made. Otherwise, a sole qualitative synthesis of included studies will be performed.
Meta-analysis 1: The chosen measure of effect size in individual trials will be the relative risk for being infected throughout the study period. The Mantel-Haenszel method will used to weight each trial.
Meta-analysis 2: The chosen measure of effect size in individual trials will be the duration of disease symptoms (measured in days) after being infected. The mean difference will be adopted to combine data of all includible studies and the inverse variance method will be used to weight each included trial.
A random-effects model will be adopted for both meta-analyses.
I² will be used as a measure of consistency. I² values of 25%, 50%, and 75% will be interpreted as representing small, moderate and high levels of heterogeneity, respectively.
If the number of studies included in each meta-analysis are sufficient (at least 10, as recommended in the Cochrane Handbook), publication bias will be assessed with a dedicated funnel plot and the Egger's test. The “p-curve” method will be adopted to further assess the risk of bias across studies and to detect any potential “p-hacking”.
If possible, a meta-regression will be performed in order to find explanations for heterogeneity, selecting as moderators the patients’ age range, the ginseng type, the geographic location of studies, and the follow-up duration. A mixed-effect model will be used, and a Restricted Maximum Likelihood method will be adopted as an estimator for τ² in the meta-analysis.
Statistical analysis will be performed with "R-Studio" by two authors (M.A.; D.D.), and, in cases of disagreement, a third author (F.F.) will be consulted to reach consensus.

q21.value: When article full-texts or essential details of included studies are missing, authors will be contacted both by email and through ResearchGate®.

q23.value: The last versione of the Cochrane risk-of-bias assessment tool (RoB 2) will be used to evaluate the quality of included trials. See this web-page for further details: https://methods.cochrane.org/bias/resources/rob-2-revised-cochrane-risk-bias-tool-randomized-trials

registration_responses.q1: Michele Antonelli, Davide Donelli, Fabio Firenzuoli
registration_responses.q2: To assess whether ginseng can be a useful supplementation for the prevention and treatment of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q9: Overall, existing data substantially suggest that ginseng might have some effects for seasonal acute upper respiratory infections, but firm conclusions on the topic cannot be driven.
registration_responses.q11: Not applicable. The review is to be performed regardless of the number of included primary studies.
registration_responses.q21: When article full-texts or essential details of included studies are missing, authors will be contacted both by email and through ResearchGate®.
registration_responses.q23: The last versione of the Cochrane risk-of-bias assessment tool (RoB 2) will be used to evaluate the quality of included trials. See this web-page for further details: https://methods.cochrane.org/bias/resources/rob-2-revised-cochrane-risk-bias-tool-randomized-trials

attributes.title: Standing out or fitting in: How gender imbalances emerge among those at the very top
attributes.description: This is an update to the registration previously posted.

summary.value:
This is to provide an update and modification to the previous preregistration.

Due to how schools in New York have closed during Spring 2020, we have decided to move this project to our lab's online data collection platform, PANDA (Princeton and NYU Discoveries in Action), and have, therefore, made minor changes to the script to accommodate this change. 

We recruit participants for this online platform, PANDA, in a multitude of ways, including but not limited to community outreach events, social media advertising, posts on Prolific, and volunteer sign-ups at our current data collection sites. For this particular study, we will only recruit participants with children between the ages of 9-10 years and 13-16 years. Parents of eligible children will be contacted via email through their PANDA account, and they will be offered the opportunity to log on and participate. Children and parents will then follow an IRB-approved consent and assent procedure. We will record the study session using participants’ webcams. The study will be presented as short videos and verbally-narrated questions, which children will respond to by clicking on the designated “buttons” to indicate their response. If children are unable to maneuver the mouse and click on the buttons themselves, parents will be encouraged to do the clicking for children (without altering their children’s responses or providing feedback in any way). However, given the age range of participants for this study, we believe that most child participants will be able to indicate responses independently. At the end of the study session, parents and children will be thanked for their participation, and parents will be given the opportunity to upload their webcam video to PANDA, where only authorized PANDA researchers may access it. Parents will also be given the option to provide consent for their data and study video to be uploaded to the Databrary database. As compensation for participation, families will receive an Amazon gift card valued at $10.

To be included, families will need to have uploaded a video successfully in which parent consent and child assent can be confirmed. All videos will also be checked to make sure a visible child is participating in order to be included. Previous work on the PANDA platform has identified extremely low rates of parent or sibling interference (less than 1% of trials), and excluding such trials had no consequence for the overall pattern of findings (Leshin, Leslie, & Rhodes, 2020). Therefore, we will randomly select 20% of the participant videos to be coded by a trained researcher in order to estimate the interference rate. If it is within the bounds of the interference level found in previous work, we will conclude that the interference level is negligible and highly unlikely to influence the study patterns and therefore retain all trials for analyses. However, if the interference rate in the subset of coded videos is more than the rate estimated from previous work, we will then code every video trial-by-trial for instances of parental interference (with 20% also checked by a reliability coder), and we will exclude any trials where the parent or a sibling interferes such that there is a question of whether the answer reflects the child’s response. If more than 25% of a child’s responses are excluded because of this reason, the participant’s data will be dropped from analyses.

Please refer to the attached documents "Rarity (Elementary) - PANDA Script.docx" and "Rarity_Elementary_PANDA.qsf" for the updated script and Qualtrics survey for the elementary-age participants. Our target age range for this part of the study will still be 9-to-10-year-old children. Our target sample size is still 128 children, with 64 children (32 boys and 32 girls) in each condition. However, given that we want to ensure that the survey is available to participants for a set period of time, we will close the survey at the end of the weekend in which we reach our target sample size. Therefore, there might be a few additional participants. We will include all participants that have completed the study in our analyses. 

We currently already have 51 elementary-age children's data collected from a New York public elementary school. We will aim to recruit the remaining 77 elementary-age children from PANDA. We have not downloaded, observed, or analyzed any of the collected 51 children's data. We will include the source of recruitment (school or PANDA) as an additional covariate in all of our statistical models to detect any potential response differences among the elementary school participants and PANDA participants.

In addition, we will also be running this study with 128 13-to-16-year-old adolescents. We have adapted the specific science questions and format to be age-appropriate, but the variables and analyses are identical to the study for elementary-age participants. Please refer to the attached documents "Rarity (Adolescents) - PANDA Script.docx" and "Rarity_Adolescents_PANDA.qsf" for the script and Qualtrics survey for the adolescent participants. Again, our target sample size is also 128 participants, with 64 participants (32 male and 32 female) in each condition. However, given that we want to ensure that the survey is available to participants for a set period of time, we will close the survey at the end of the weekend in which we reach our target sample size. Therefore, there might be a few additional participants. We will include all participants that have completed the study in our analyses.

Because of this change in our recruitment method, we also want to provide parents with additional information about the science questions we ask in the study, in case they want to provide further guidance and discussion for their children. Therefore, for both participant groups, we include in the survey a document for parents that includes a complete list of the science concepts, questions, answers, and explanations for all five science questions that participants might have encountered. Please refer to the documents "Science Questions_Elementary School.pdf" and "Science Questions_Adolescents.pdf" for the questions, answers, and explanations for the elementary-age participants and adolescent participants, respectively.

registration_responses.summary:
This is to provide an update and modification to the previous preregistration.

Due to how schools in New York have closed during Spring 2020, we have decided to move this project to our lab's online data collection platform, PANDA (Princeton and NYU Discoveries in Action), and have, therefore, made minor changes to the script to accommodate this change.

attributes.title: Breaking Down Barriers to Naturalization for Low-Income Immigrants: The Impact of Information

q1.value: Breaking Down Barriers to Naturalization for Low-Income Immigrants: The Impact of Information

q2.value: Jens Hainmueller | Michael Hotard | David Laitin | Duncan Lawrence

q5.value: This project was funded by Robin Hood (Grant SPO 123714) and The New York Community Trust (Grant P16-000101).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: What are effective interventions for encouraging immigrants to apply for naturalization? In 2016, the New York State Office for New Americans launched NaturalizeNY, a public-private program that aims to improve the lives of immigrants by increasing access to naturalization (the associated pre-registered evaluation is described in EGAP ID: 20170503AC). In 2017, the second year of NaturalizeNY, and as part of the larger NaturalizeNY program, this randomized controlled trial will investigate the effect of providing low-income immigrants with information about their fee waiver eligibility on the probability of applying for naturalization. In order to become a US citizen, an immigrant must meet a number of eligibility requirements and complete an application for naturalization. Normally, the application requires a fee that in 2017 was $725 or $405 (depending on income). For low-income immigrants, this fee may serve as a barrier for seeking naturalization. In addition, very low-income immigrants whose household income falls at or below 150% of the Federal Poverty Guidelines or who receive means-tested bene fits (MTBs) from the government are typically eligible for a federal fee waiver that waives the application fee. However, awareness of the the federal fee waiver program varies widely and therefore immigrants who are eligible might not use it because they are not aware that they qualify for a fee waiver.

q16.value: We are testing whether providing lawful permanent residents who are likely eligible for the federal fee waiver program with basic information about the program significantly increases the likelihood of applying for citizenship. We anticipate this low-cost informational treatment will have a positive and significant effect on application rates.

q17.value: The hypothesis will be tested using an RCT. Individuals registering for NaturalizeNY in 2017 were screened for fee waiver eligibility and those likely eligible for the waiver were included in the study. The treatment assignment takes place at the time of registration and registrants were randomly assigned to the treatment group with probability 3/4 and to the control group with probability 1/4. Those in the treatment group receive a message from the registration system that informs them that they potentially qualify for a fee waiver from the federal government. Those in the control group receive a placebo message from the registration system that did not include the information about the potential eligibility for the fee waiver from the federal government (note: control group participants are eventually informed of potential eligibility after completing the follow-up survey). All study participants are asked to participate in a follow-up survey to measure the key outcome of interest: whether an individual applied for naturalization.

attributes.title: Demographic threat and the classification of ambiguously White/Latino faces

q1.value: Demographic threat and the classification of ambiguously White/Latino faces

q5.value: I gratefully acknowledge support from Columbia University.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: When Whites are exposed to information about the changing demographics of the US, are they more or less likely to classify ambiguously White/Latino people as “White”? To answer this question, I carry out an online survey experiment with 500 US Whites who are randomly assigned to one of two conditions. Participants assigned to the control condition begin the survey by studying a graph that shows modest changes in the racial/ethnic composition of the US population between 2000 and 2025. Participants assigned to the treatment condition begin the survey by studying a graph that shows dramatic changes in the racial/ethnic composition of the US population between 1960 and 2060. Next, participants classify faces, sourced from the Chicago Face Database, in terms of race/ethnicity.

q16.value: H1. Participants in the treatment group will be less likely to classify ambiguously White/Latino faces as “White.” H2. Participants in the treatment group will be more likely to classify ambiguously White/Latino faces as “White.”  H3. Participants in the treatment group will be neither more nor less likely to classify unambiguous “filler” faces as “White.”

q17.value: I test these hypotheses using an online survey experiment. Participants (500 US adults who identify as “White”) are recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants are randomly assigned to one of two conditions. Participants assigned to the control condition begin the survey by studying a graph that shows modest changes in the racial/ethnic composition of the US population between 2000 and 2025. Participants assigned to the treatment condition begin the survey by studying a graph that shows dramatic changes in the racial/ethnic composition of the US population between 1960 and 2060. These graphs are modeled closely after the primes designed and used by Wetts and Willer (2018). Next, participants classify 18 faces, sourced from the Chicago Face Database, in terms of race/ethnicity. Eight of these faces are ambiguously White/Latino.

attributes.title: A Living Systematic Review for COVID-19 Clinical Trial Registrations
attributes.description: This living systematic review aims to provide an open, accessible and frequently updated resource summarising the characteristics of COVID-19 clinical trial registrations. Weekly search updates of the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) and source registries will be conducted.

attributes.title: State Immigration Policy and Immigrant Health

q1.value: State Immigration Policy and Immigrant Health

q2.value: Ala' Alrababa'h | Vasiliki Fouka | Jens Hainmueller | Daniel Hopkins | Michael Hotard | Duncan Lawrence | Rita Hamad

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Over the past decade, several states debated and implemented policies targeting immigrants. Among other measures, these policies limited immigrants’ access to public services, such as healthcare, and called for more stringent enforcement by local and state police in identifying and detaining undocumented immigrants. While there have been several studies about the impact of these policies on the health of immigrants and ethnic minorities, they are mainly correlational and highly contextual. In this study, we propose to examine the causal effect of state-level immigration policies on the mental health and health behavior of immigrants. We hypothesize that proposing and implementing anti-immigrant policies will worsen the mental health of immigrants and ethnic minorities. We also expect that this effect will be conditioned by the salience of the issue within a given state; the more aware people are of the anti-immigrant policies, the more likely they are to have worse mental health outcomes. To establish the causal effect of immigration policies on the mental health of immigrants and ethnic minorities, we plan to use a difference-in-differences approach. In this study, we hope to examine whether there is a causal relationship between discussing, proposing, and implementing anti-immigrant policies in states and the mental health of immigrants and ethnic minorities. We will combine data on the mental health and health behavior of individuals and their demographic information from the United States National Health Interview Survey with data we have coded on the salience of immigration issues in each state, the proposal of restrictive immigration legislation in state legislatures, and the implementation of such legislation.

q16.value: Our primary outcome is on the mental health of immigrants. We hypothesize that proposing and implementing anti-immigrant policies will worsen the mental health of immigrants and ethnic minorities. This outcome will be measured using the Kessler-6 scores in the NHIS. We will also report on other health outcomes that may be affected, such as general reported health and health utilization. For each group of outcomes, we will examine the outcomes individually as well as build an index for these outcomes. The indices will include the following: mental health (all respondents), mental health (children), other health outcomes (adults), other health outcomes (children), behavioral outcomes (adults), utilization of health facilities (adults), utilization of health facilities (children). Please see the Pre-Analysis plan for the full set of outcomes.

q17.value: We will use a difference-in-difference approach to measure the effects of the anti-immigrant policies. Our unit of analysis is the individual. We will run the following model. The model estimates the effect of anti-immigrant policy on the health outcomes of interest among affected populations. Yist = beta_0 + beta _1 Proposedist + beta _2 Treatedist + beta _3 (Treatedist x Proposedist) + beta_4 Xist + Statei + Yeart + (Statei x Yeart) + e_ist (1) Yist = beta _0 + beta _1 Salienceist + beta _2 Treatedist + beta _3 (Treatedist x Salienceist) + beta _4 Xist + Statei + Yeart + (Statei x Yeart) + e_ist (1) These equations represent a repeated cross-sectional model with two-way fixed effects. Y is the health outcome of interest for individual i in state s at time t (e.g. k-6 scores). Proposed is a dummy variable which will be coded as 1 between the time that the law was proposed until it was overturned. In other models, we also code proposed as 1 following the time the law was proposed until the end of our data (so it is not coded as 0 after it is overturned). Also, we run other models replacing Proposed with each of the following: signed and implemented. Treated indicates whether the individual is belongs to a treated group (such as an ethnic minority). Salience indicates whether immigration is a highly salient issue, based on the newspaper reports that we coded. X represents individual-level confounders, State represents state-level fixed effects, and Year is a time-fixed effect. The interaction between State and Year allows for state specific time trends. Finally, e is the error term, which will be clustered at the state level.

q19.value: The study uses data from the National Health Interview Survey for 1996-2017; a total of ~1,785,000 records. This study will focus on self-identified Hispanic/Latino respondents.

q23.value: Because the research team will not obtain any identifying information about the participants, it is not considered human subjects research. This determination was made by the Stanford IRB.

q27.value: This will study the effect of policies implemented by state governments.

attributes.title: Context-nonspecific familiarity and novelty detection deficits in subclinical paranoia and referential thinking
attributes.description:
Patients with schizophrenia show impaired episodic and recognition memory (Aleman et al., 1999), but the mechanisms by which such impairments may participate in the formation or maintenance of psychotic symptoms such as delusions remain unclear. The ability to detect novel stimuli relies on one’s capacity to hold and contrast items and events in memory. Detecting novelty in one’s environment is a key process in flexible learning and belief updating; decreased sensitivity to novel information may interfere with one’s ability to form new associations. Past research has shown abnormalities in novelty detection among individuals with schizophrenia (Schott et al., 2015; Weiss et al., 2004; Weiss et al., 2008) and, more specifically, susceptibility to and/or overconfidence in “false memories” (i.e., a false positive on a memory task, often using lures that are semantically related to targets as in a Deese-Roediger-McDermott paradigm; Evans et al., 2019; Bhat et al., 2010; Moritz et al., 2006; Lee et al., 2007). However, neither the processes that support these aberrancies nor the broader implications for delusional belief have been fully explored. To this end, the present study aims to investigate how delusion-prone individuals experience novel stimuli and how the detection of novelty may be impaired due to over-reliance on non-contextually-specific familiarity cues.

In the absence of clear episodic recollections, low-level “fluency” heuristics may guide memory judgements. Past research has probed this phenomenon via “Remember-Know” paradigms, which have provided evidence that individuals with schizophrenia are particularly reliant on familiarity assessments as a basis for retrieval (e.g., Achim & Lepage, 2005; Erp et al., 2008; Libby et al., 2013). Over-reliance on familiarity-based heuristics makes it difficult to tag particular instances of a stimulus to a particular learning context and could thereby contribute to undue salience of stimuli incidental to the current context – a phenomenon thought to participate in delusions such as paranoia and referential thinking (Kapur, 2003), possibly through its contribution to the precision of prediction errors (Diaconescu et al., 2019; Fletcher & Frith, 2009). Furthermore, cognitive models of delusional belief put forward a bias towards “liberal acceptance” as a key contributor to the formation of fixed false belief, drawing from evidence that delusional individuals tend to employ liberal decision thresholds, collecting less evidence before arriving at a highly confident conclusion (Moritz et al., 2008). In the context of a recognition memory paradigm, task-irrelevant familiarity information may thus be sufficient to surmount delusional individuals’ already-liberal “old/new” decision thresholds (also supported by Erp et al., 2008), manifesting in an impaired ability to detect stimuli that are contextually, but not absolutely, novel. If individuals high in delusionality are reliant on such fluency cues in recognition memory, one would expect memory performance to be impaired for familiar stimuli but relatively more intact for stimuli to which they have had no prior exposure. In other words, delusional or delusion-prone individuals would be predicted to show a greater propensity to report false alarms (i.e., mistaking a “new” stimulus for an “old” stimulus) in the context of stimuli that are encountered with high frequency (i.e., multiple contexts) in everyday life relative to stimuli to that are unfamiliar. In conjunction with delusional individuals’ tendency to report high confidence in errors (see Balzan et al., 2016 for a recent review), such an effect may manifest as overconfident failures in novelty detection that are particularly pronounced among familiar stimuli.

To explore these predictions, the present study seeks to determine whether over-reliance on fluency-based mechanisms during retrieval is associated with higher levels of delusion-proneness in the general population by testing whether the relationship between delusionality and memory deficits is more pronounced in the context of familiar stimuli (i.e., real words) relative to unfamiliar stimuli (i.e., pseudo words). More specifically, this study seeks to replicate and extend preliminary findings that point to an association between paranoia and deficits in novelty detection specifically in the context of familiar stimuli by a) replicating findings in a larger sample and b) testing this effect in individuals who endorse ideas of reference as well as paranoia. Characterizing this phenomenon may help to answer broader questions regarding the circumstances under which new information – which, in the real world, can come in the form of novel evidence that disconfirms strongly held beliefs – may fail to be detected by delusional individuals and how this may relate to experiences of aberrant salience.

q2.value:
1.	Response Type: High-delusionality individuals will make a greater proportion of false alarms relative to low-delusionality individuals on real-word trials relative to pseudo-word trials.
2.	Confidence: High-delusionality individuals will report higher confidence on errors (i.e., false alarms and misses) than low-delusionality individuals on both real- and pseudo-word trials.
3.	Meta-d’: High-delusionality individuals will show lower meta-d’ (a measure of the extent to which one’s confidence ratings are predictive of one’s actual success) relative to low-delusionality individuals on real-word trials relative to pseudo-word trials.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Mixed between- and within-subjects design, with paranoia and ideas of reference measured by the Revised Green Paranoid Thoughts Scale (R-GPTS; Freeman et al., 2019) using both subscales (persecution and reference). Memory ability will be assessed using a recognition memory task with a within-subjects manipulation of word familiarity.

Participants will complete an online survey that will include the R-GPTS (both Persecution and Reference subscales), the Aberrant Salience Index (ASI; Cicero, Kerns, & McCarthy, 2010), as well as a novel recognition memory task comprising real words (e.g., “bike”) and pseudo words (e.g, “rimp”). During an encoding phase, which will take place before the R-GPTS and the ASI, participants will be shown 40 words (20 real, 20 pseudo), appearing in random order for 4 seconds each. During a recognition phase, which will take place after the R-GPTS and the ASI, participants will be presented with 80 words (40 real, 40 pseudo) in random order. Half of these words (20 real, 20 pseudo) will have been presented during encoding (i.e., targets). The other half will not have been presented during encoding (i.e., lures). For each word, participants will be asked if they think it is “old” (i.e., presented during encoding) or “new” (i.e., not presented during encoding). Then, participants will be asked to rate their confidence in this response on a scale of 1 (very unsure) to 4 (very sure). In both cases, the survey will auto-advance once a response is logged or after 4.5 seconds elapse. The survey will conclude with a demographics section (age, sex, level of education, race/ethnicity, and primary language) and a screener question querying random responding (“Did you respond randomly at any point during the study? Responding randomly means clicking a response without reading the question or without thinking about the answer at all - it does NOT mean making a guess because you were unsure of the correct answer. Note: Please be honest! You will get your HIT regardless of your response.”).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 275 participants will be recruited via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk platform to complete an online Qualtrics survey. This survey will be open only to workers located in the United States with a HIT approval rate above 95% and more than 100 completed HITs. Workers who took part in a pilot study using similar measures will be precluded from taking the survey.

q11.value: 275 participants will be recruited. The final sample size will depend on the number of participants excluded via the criteria outlined in "Data collection procedures".

question.value: Recognition memory will be examined in two conditions (real words and pseudo-words) and in two trial types (targets and lures). Paranoia and ideas of reference will be indexed by the R-GPTS and will be analyzed by group (high delusionality and low delusionality). Cutoffs will be determined by the R-GPTS recommendations for moderate severity (11 in the case of the persecution subscale – recommended to discriminate clinical levels of paranoid ideation – and 16 in the case of the reference subscale).

Experiences of aberrant salience (measured using the ASI), age, sex, level of education, race/ethnicity, primary language. As previously mentioned, delusionality will be measured using the R-GPTS (Persecution and Reference subscales) before participants are broken into high- and low-delusionality groups using the cut-offs described above.

All items on questionnaires (R-GPTS, ASI) will be summed to generate a total score. Additionally, subscale items (e.g., Persecution and Reference subscale of the R-GPTS) will be summed to create subscale scores.

For Hypothesis 1, a mixed-effects logistic regression will be carried out on the trial-by-trial counts of false alarms and misses (i.e., 1s and 0s) from the recognition memory task. A false alarm will be coded with a 1 if a participant responded “old” on a “new” trial; 0 if “new” on a “new: trial. A miss will be coded with a 1 if a participant responded “new” on an “old” trial; 0 if “old” on an “old” trial. Note that correct rejections and hits are direct inverses of false alarms and misses, respectively, and thus do not necessitate the creation odf separate models. The mixed-effects logistic regression will be run in R via the glmer function of the lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015), using binomial family and specifying subject ID as a random effect. This model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo) and will include age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package (Lenth, 2020). Individual models will be created for false alarm trials and miss trials.

For Hypothesis 2, a mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression will be carried out on the trial-by-trial ratings of confidence. Confidence will be analyzed as an ordinal variable, increasing in 1-unit increments from 1 to 4. The mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression will be run in R using the clmm function of the ordinal package (Christensen, 2019), using binomial family and specifying subject ID as a random effect. This model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo). Models that show no significant interaction effect will be re-run with no interaction term looking at the main effect of delusionality only (high vs. low). In both cases, the models will include age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package. Individual models will be created for false alarm trials, correct rejection trials, miss trials, and hit trials.

For Hypothesis 3, a repeated-measures ANOVA will be conducted on meta-d’ scores (HMeta-d; calculated using methods described in Fleming, 2017). The repeated-measures ANOVA will be conducted using the aov function in base R. The model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo). Word familiarity will be specified as a within-subject variable. Age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity will be included as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package.

q18.value:
Ideas of reference and paranoia scores will be calculated by summing responses on the Revised Green Paranoid Thoughts Scale (R-GPTS), with a higher score representing higher levels of delusionality. As previously mentioned, high delusion and low delusion groups will be formed using the cutoffs for moderate severity (11 for Persecution subscale, 16 for Reference subscale). 

See "Statistical models" for more information on how false alarms, correct rejections, misses, and hits are coded.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance on all models and post-hoc tests.

q20.value:
Individuals who respond to less than 50% of the items on the memory task, or who are more than one standard deviation below chance responding (50% accuracy), will be excluded from further analysis. Additionally, individuals who responded “Yes” to the screener question described previously (“Did you respond randomly at any point during the study...”) will be excluded. Finally, participants whose primary language is not English will be excluded, given that the manipulation of word familiarity depends on frequent exposure to the real word stimuli which are all in English.

Outliers in skewed data will be identified using methods outlined by Hubert & Van der Veeken (2008), as implemented in R’s RobustBase package (Todorov & Filzmoser, 2010). Outliers in normally distributed data will be identified as data points more than 3 standard deviations from the sample mean. In all cases, outliers will be replaced with winsorized values (while preserving rank order).

q21.value: Missing values on key measures (R-GPTS, ASI) will be imputed based on the participant’s mean score on all other items of the subscale in question.

q23.value:
References

Achim, A. M., & Lepage, M. (2005). Episodic memory-related activation in schizophrenia: meta-analysis. Br J Psychiatry, 187, 500-509.

Aleman, A., Hijman, R., de Haan, E. H. F., & Kahn, R. S. (1999). Memory Impairment in Schizophrenia: A Meta-Analysis. The American Journal of Psychiatry, 156(9), 1358-1366.

Balzan, R. P., & Hodkinson, K. (2016). Overconfidence in psychosis: The foundation of delusional conviction? Cogent Psychology, 3(1). doi:10.1080/23311908.2015.1135855

Bates, D., Maechler, M., Bolker, B., & Walker, S. (2015). Fitting Linear Mixed-Effects Models Using lme4. Journal of Statistical Software, 67. doi:10.18637/jss.v067.i01

Bhatt, R., Laws, K. R., & McKenna, P. J. (2010). False memory in schizophrenia patients with and without delusions. Psychiatry Res, 178(2), 260-265. doi:10.1016/j.psychres.2009.02.006

Christensen, R. (2019). ordinal - Regression Models for Ordinal Data. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/package=ordinal.

Cicero, D. C., Kerns, J. G., & McCarthy, D. M. (2010). The Aberrant Salience Inventory: a new measure of psychosis proneness. Psychol Assess, 22(3), 688-701. doi:10.1037/a0019913

Diaconescu, A. O., Hauke, D. J., & Borgwardt, S. (2019). Models of persecutory delusions: a mechanistic insight into the early stages of psychosis. Mol Psychiatry, 24(9), 1258-1267. doi:10.1038/s41380-019-0427-z

Erp, T. G. M. v., Lesh, T. A., Knowlton, B. J., Bearden, C. E., Hardt, M., Karlsgodt, K. H., . . . Cannon, T. D. (2008). Remember and Know Judgments During Recognition in Chronic Schizophrenia. Schizophr Res., 100(1-3), 181-190.

Evans, L. H., McCann, H. M., Isgar, J. G., & Gaston, A. (2019). High delusional ideation is associated with false pictorial memory. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry, 62, 97-102. doi:10.1016/j.jbtep.2018.09.005

Fleming, S. M. (2017). HMeta-d: hierarchical Bayesian estimation of metacognitive efficiency from confidence ratings. Neurosci Conscious, 2017(1), nix007. doi:10.1093/nc/nix007
Freeman, D., Loe, B. S., Kingdon, D., Startup, H., Molodynski, A., Rosebrock, L., . . . Bird, J. C. (2019). The revised Green et al., Paranoid Thoughts Scale (R-GPTS): psychometric properties, severity ranges, and clinical cut-offs. Psychol Med, 1-10. doi:10.1017/S0033291719003155

Fletcher, P. C., & Frith, C. D. (2009). Perceiving is believing: a Bayesian approach to explaining the positive symptoms of schizophrenia. Nat Rev Neurosci, 10(1), 48-58. doi:10.1038/nrn2536

Hubert, M., & Van der Veeken, S. (2008). Outlier detection for skewed data. Journal of Chemometrics, 22(3-4), 235-246. doi:10.1002/cem.1123

Kapur, S. (2003). Psychosis as a State of Aberrant Salience: A Framework Linking Biology, Phenomenology, and Pharmacology in Schizophrenia. Am J Psychiatry, 160(1), 13-23. 

Lee, Y. S., Iao, L. S., & Lin, C. W. (2007). False memory and schizophrenia: evidence for gist memory impairment. Psychol Med, 37(4), 559-567. doi:10.1017/S0033291706009044

Lenth, R. (2020). Estimate Marginal Means, aka Least-Squares Means. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/

Libby, L. A., Yonelinas, A. P., Ranganath, C., & Ragland, J. D. (2013). Recollection and familiarity in schizophrenia: a quantitative review. Biol Psychiatry, 73(10), 944-950. doi:10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.10.027

Moritz, S., Woodward, T. S., Jelinek, L., & Klinge, R. (2008). Memory and metamemory in schizophrenia: a liberal acceptance account of psychosis. Psychol Med, 38(6), 825-832. doi:10.1017/S0033291707002553

Moritz, S., Woodward, T. S., & Rodriguez-Raecke, R. (2006). Patients with schizophrenia do not produce more false memories than controls but are more confident in them. Psychol Med, 36(5), 659-667. doi:10.1017/S0033291706007252

registration_responses.q2:
1.	Response Type: High-delusionality individuals will make a greater proportion of false alarms relative to low-delusionality individuals on real-word trials relative to pseudo-word trials.
2.	Confidence: High-delusionality individuals will report higher confidence on errors (i.e., false alarms and misses) than low-delusionality individuals on both real- and pseudo-word trials.
3.	Meta-d’: High-delusionality individuals will show lower meta-d’ (a measure of the extent to which one’s confidence ratings are predictive of one’s actual success) relative to low-delusionality individuals on real-word trials relative to pseudo-word trials.
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: 275 participants will be recruited. The final sample size will depend on the number of participants excluded via the criteria outlined in "Data collection procedures".
registration_responses.q18:
Ideas of reference and paranoia scores will be calculated by summing responses on the Revised Green Paranoid Thoughts Scale (R-GPTS), with a higher score representing higher levels of delusionality. As previously mentioned, high delusion and low delusion groups will be formed using the cutoffs for moderate severity (11 for Persecution subscale, 16 for Reference subscale). 

See "Statistical models" for more information on how false alarms, correct rejections, misses, and hits are coded.
registration_responses.q19: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance on all models and post-hoc tests.
registration_responses.q20:
Individuals who respond to less than 50% of the items on the memory task, or who are more than one standard deviation below chance responding (50% accuracy), will be excluded from further analysis. Additionally, individuals who responded “Yes” to the screener question described previously (“Did you respond randomly at any point during the study...”) will be excluded. Finally, participants whose primary language is not English will be excluded, given that the manipulation of word familiarity depends on frequent exposure to the real word stimuli which are all in English.

Outliers in skewed data will be identified using methods outlined by Hubert & Van der Veeken (2008), as implemented in R’s RobustBase package (Todorov & Filzmoser, 2010). Outliers in normally distributed data will be identified as data points more than 3 standard deviations from the sample mean. In all cases, outliers will be replaced with winsorized values (while preserving rank order).
registration_responses.q21: Missing values on key measures (R-GPTS, ASI) will be imputed based on the participant’s mean score on all other items of the subscale in question.
registration_responses.q23:
References

Balzan, R. P., & Hodkinson, K. (2016). Overconfidence in psychosis: The foundation of delusional conviction? Cogent Psychology, 3(1). doi:10.1080/23311908.2015.1135855

Bhatt, R., Laws, K. R., & McKenna, P. J. (2010). False memory in schizophrenia patients with and without delusions. Psychiatry Res, 178(2), 260-265. doi:10.1016/j.psychres.2009.02.006

Cicero, D. C., Kerns, J. G., & McCarthy, D. M. (2010). The Aberrant Salience Inventory: a new measure of psychosis proneness. Psychol Assess, 22(3), 688-701. doi:10.1037/a0019913

Diaconescu, A. O., Hauke, D. J., & Borgwardt, S. (2019). Models of persecutory delusions: a mechanistic insight into the early stages of psychosis. Mol Psychiatry, 24(9), 1258-1267. doi:10.1038/s41380-019-0427-z

Erp, T. G. M. v., Lesh, T. A., Knowlton, B. J., Bearden, C. E., Hardt, M., Karlsgodt, K. H., . . . Cannon, T. D. (2008). Remember and Know Judgments During Recognition in Chronic Schizophrenia. Schizophr Res., 100(1-3), 181-190.

Evans, L. H., McCann, H. M., Isgar, J. G., & Gaston, A. (2019). High delusional ideation is associated with false pictorial memory. J Behav Ther Exp Psychiatry, 62, 97-102. doi:10.1016/j.jbtep.2018.09.005

Fleming, S. M. (2017). HMeta-d: hierarchical Bayesian estimation of metacognitive efficiency from confidence ratings. Neurosci Conscious, 2017(1), nix007. doi:10.1093/nc/nix007

Fletcher, P. C., & Frith, C. D. (2009). Perceiving is believing: a Bayesian approach to explaining the positive symptoms of schizophrenia. Nat Rev Neurosci, 10(1), 48-58. doi:10.1038/nrn2536

Hubert, M., & Van der Veeken, S. (2008). Outlier detection for skewed data. Journal of Chemometrics, 22(3-4), 235-246. doi:10.1002/cem.1123

Kapur, S. (2003). Psychosis as a State of Aberrant Salience: A Framework Linking Biology, Phenomenology, and Pharmacology in Schizophrenia. Am J Psychiatry, 160(1), 13-23. 

Lee, Y. S., Iao, L. S., & Lin, C. W. (2007). False memory and schizophrenia: evidence for gist memory impairment. Psychol Med, 37(4), 559-567. doi:10.1017/S0033291706009044

Lenth, R. (2020). Estimate Marginal Means, aka Least-Squares Means. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/

Libby, L. A., Yonelinas, A. P., Ranganath, C., & Ragland, J. D. (2013). Recollection and familiarity in schizophrenia: a quantitative review. Biol Psychiatry, 73(10), 944-950. doi:10.1016/j.biopsych.2012.10.027

Moritz, S., Woodward, T. S., Jelinek, L., & Klinge, R. (2008). Memory and metamemory in schizophrenia: a liberal acceptance account of psychosis. Psychol Med, 38(6), 825-832. doi:10.1017/S0033291707002553

Moritz, S., Woodward, T. S., & Rodriguez-Raecke, R. (2006). Patients with schizophrenia do not produce more false memories than controls but are more confident in them. Psychol Med, 36(5), 659-667. doi:10.1017/S0033291706007252
registration_responses.q6.question:
Mixed between- and within-subjects design, with paranoia and ideas of reference measured by the Revised Green Paranoid Thoughts Scale (R-GPTS; Freeman et al., 2019) using both subscales (persecution and reference). Memory ability will be assessed using a recognition memory task with a within-subjects manipulation of word familiarity.

Participants will complete an online survey that will include the R-GPTS (both Persecution and Reference subscales), the Aberrant Salience Index (ASI; Cicero, Kerns, & McCarthy, 2010), as well as a novel recognition memory task comprising real words (e.g., “bike”) and pseudo words (e.g, “rimp”). During an encoding phase, which will take place before the R-GPTS and the ASI, participants will be shown 40 words (20 real, 20 pseudo), appearing in random order for 4 seconds each. During a recognition phase, which will take place after the R-GPTS and the ASI, participants will be presented with 80 words (40 real, 40 pseudo) in random order. Half of these words (20 real, 20 pseudo) will have been presented during encoding (i.e., targets). The other half will not have been presented during encoding (i.e., lures). For each word, participants will be asked if they think it is “old” (i.e., presented during encoding) or “new” (i.e., not presented during encoding). Then, participants will be asked to rate their confidence in this response on a scale of 1 (very unsure) to 4 (very sure). In both cases, the survey will auto-advance once a response is logged or after 4.5 seconds elapse. The survey will conclude with a demographics section (age, sex, level of education, race/ethnicity, and primary language) and a screener question querying random responding (“Did you respond randomly at any point during the study? Responding randomly means clicking a response without reading the question or without thinking about the answer at all - it does NOT mean making a guess because you were unsure of the correct answer. Note: Please be honest! You will get your HIT regardless of your response.”).
registration_responses.q10.question: 275 participants will be recruited via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk platform to complete an online Qualtrics survey. This survey will be open only to workers located in the United States with a HIT approval rate above 95% and more than 100 completed HITs. Workers who took part in a pilot study using similar measures will be precluded from taking the survey.
registration_responses.q14.question: Recognition memory will be examined in two conditions (real words and pseudo-words) and in two trial types (targets and lures). Paranoia and ideas of reference will be indexed by the R-GPTS and will be analyzed by group (high delusionality and low delusionality). Cutoffs will be determined by the R-GPTS recommendations for moderate severity (11 in the case of the persecution subscale – recommended to discriminate clinical levels of paranoid ideation – and 16 in the case of the reference subscale).
registration_responses.q15.question: Experiences of aberrant salience (measured using the ASI), age, sex, level of education, race/ethnicity, primary language. As previously mentioned, delusionality will be measured using the R-GPTS (Persecution and Reference subscales) before participants are broken into high- and low-delusionality groups using the cut-offs described above.
registration_responses.q16.question: All items on questionnaires (R-GPTS, ASI) will be summed to generate a total score. Additionally, subscale items (e.g., Persecution and Reference subscale of the R-GPTS) will be summed to create subscale scores.
registration_responses.q17.question:
For Hypothesis 1, a mixed-effects logistic regression will be carried out on the trial-by-trial counts of false alarms and misses (i.e., 1s and 0s) from the recognition memory task. A false alarm will be coded with a 1 if a participant responded “old” on a “new” trial; 0 if “new” on a “new: trial. A miss will be coded with a 1 if a participant responded “new” on an “old” trial; 0 if “old” on an “old” trial. Note that correct rejections and hits are direct inverses of false alarms and misses, respectively, and thus do not necessitate the creation odf separate models. The mixed-effects logistic regression will be run in R via the glmer function of the lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015), using binomial family and specifying subject ID as a random effect. This model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo) and will include age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package (Lenth, 2020). Individual models will be created for false alarm trials and miss trials.

For Hypothesis 2, a mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression will be carried out on the trial-by-trial ratings of confidence. Confidence will be analyzed as an ordinal variable, increasing in 1-unit increments from 1 to 4. The mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression will be run in R using the clmm function of the ordinal package (Christensen, 2019), using binomial family and specifying subject ID as a random effect. This model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo). Models that show no significant interaction effect will be re-run with no interaction term looking at the main effect of delusionality only (high vs. low). In both cases, the models will include age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package. Individual models will be created for false alarm trials, correct rejection trials, miss trials, and hit trials.

For Hypothesis 3, a repeated-measures ANOVA will be conducted on meta-d’ scores (HMeta-d; calculated using methods described in Fleming, 2017). The repeated-measures ANOVA will be conducted using the aov function in base R. The model will include an interaction term for delusion group (high vs. low) by word familiarity condition (real vs. pseudo). Word familiarity will be specified as a within-subject variable. Age, sex, education, and race/ethnicity will be included as covariates. Contrasts will be performed using the emmeans package.
